item.title: Destiny 2: Eternal Title Guide (All Triumphs)
item.description:
A new day dawns on Destiny 2 with the Rite of the Nine event, which provides players with three dungeons to play entirely for free. Spire of the Watcher, Ghosts of the Deep, and Prophecy are all free to play thanks to the Rite of the Nine event, but that's not all. Players can jump into this event to test their might to become ETERNAL with a new title exclusive to this event in Destiny 2 .

The ETERNAL title sounds cool, and is pretty challenging to complete due to what it asks of players when they indulge in the hardest difficulties of the dungeons present. Players can find every Triumph for the ETERNAL title below and how to complete them so that they can impress the Nine before the launch of Destiny 2: The Edge of Fate .

All Eternal Title Triumphs and How to Complete Them in Destiny 2

There are 9 Triumphs involved in the ETERNAL title for Destiny 2 , and they might take a competent fireteam to complete due to the difficult nature of some of the encounters, especially when most of the Triumphs require a completion of each dungeon with Gold Score on the Ultimatum Difficulty, which is the hardest difficulty and requires less than 2 kills every encounter:

Triumph

Description

How to Complete

Seasoned Dungeoneer

Complete all of the Into the Dungeon quests.

The Into the Dungeon quests are the first Elegant Arsenal quests that players can complete by finishing the required dungeon.

Foiled Again

Complete all nine Elegant Arsenal quests

There will be one Elegant Arsenal quest a week, and they usually involve completing the weekly dungeon from the Rite of the Nine event.

Seeker of the Nine

Find all six hidden collectibles in the Spire of the Watcher, Ghosts of the Deep, and Prophecy dungeons in any mode: Explorer, Eternity, or Ultimatum.

There are 2 hidden collectibles within each of the 3 dungeons, and they look like golden engrams. These can be found in any mode from Explorer, Eternity, to Ultimatum.

Who Watches

Earn Gold score for each encounter in the Spire of the Watcher dungeon on Eternity mode.

A gold score can be obtained by completing each of the 3 encounters without dying more than twice:

  • Spire Ascent encounter
  • Akelous, the Siren's Current
  • Persys, Primordial Ruin

Peak of the Spire

Earn Gold score for each encounter in the Spire of the Watcher dungeon on Ultimatum mode.

A gold score can be obtained by completing each of the 3 encounters without dying more than once:

  • Spire Ascent encounter
  • Akelous, the Siren's Current
  • Persys, Primordial Ruin

Down in the Depths

Earn Gold score for each encounter in the Ghosts of the Deep dungeon on Eternity mode.

A gold score can be obtained by completing each of the 3 encounters without dying more than twice:

  • Hive Ritual
  • Ecthar, the Shield of Savathun
  • Simmumah ur-Nokru

The Deepest Commitment

Earn Gold score for each encounter in the Spire of the Watcher dungeon on Ultimatum mode.

A gold score can be obtained by completing each of the 3 encounters without dying more than once:

  • Hive Ritual
  • Ecthar, the Shield of Savathun
  • Simmumah ur-Nokru

As War Foretold

Earn Gold score for each encounter in the Prophecy dungeon on Eternity mode.

A gold score can be obtained by completing each of the 3 encounters without dying more than twice:

  • Heaven/Hell
  • Hexahedron
  • Singularity

Vision of the Future

Earn Gold score for each encounter in the Prophecy dungeon on Ultimatum mode.

A gold score can be obtained by completing each of the 3 encounters without dying more than once:

  • Heaven/Hell
  • Hexahedron
  • Singularity

Running the Gauntlet

Complete a Dungeon Gauntlet from beginning to end.

Dungeon Gauntlets have not yet been added to Destiny 2 's Rite of the Nine event, so not much information can be provided at this time.

Destiny 2
44
7.7 /10

August 28, 2017

item.title: Death Stranding 2's 'Boss Skip' Feature Could Be a Game-Changer
item.description:
Though it won't be for everyone, Death Stranding 2: On the Beach is poised to be one of 2025's most intriguing projects. Following 2019's Death Stranding , which was the debut of the newly independent Kojima Productions, Death Stranding 2 will follow several of the heroes from the first game as they journey through Kojima's bizarre, uncanny apocalyptic future.

As one might expect from a Hideo Kojima game, Death Stranding 2 will almost certainly be full of surprises, offering new gameplay and narrative twists that subvert audience expectations. At the same time, its role as a sequel could inform much of its design, with Kojima and his teammates working to polish up some of the weaker areas of the first game while doubling down on its strengths. Put another way, Death Stranding 2 isn't entering the games industry as fresh-faced and untested as its predecessor: it will be rubbing up against audience expectations, feedback, and the foundation set by the first entry. Naturally, Kojima games march to the beat of their own drum, but it looks like at least one major feature has been implemented with the aim of making DS2 more player-friendly, and it's being executed in a rather unique manner.

Death Stranding 2's Boss Skip Feature Is a Surprising New Addition

The Ability To Skip Bosses in Death Stranding 2 Is a Win for Accessibility

According to Kojima himself, Death Stranding 2 will allow players to skip bosses that they find too difficult. After dying to a boss, there will be a button to skip the battle in addition to the regular restart/continue button. If players choose to skip, they will be presented with a novel-like text description of the battle, coupled with relevant images. It's not entirely clear if this option will be available to all players, or only those playing Death Stranding 2 on easier difficulties. Similarly, it's unclear whether this option will appear upon the player's first failure, or if it requires repeated deaths to activate.

Either way, this seems like a thoughtful way to approach combat accessibility. Death Stranding 2 is far from the first game to allow players to skip significant challenges— Red Dead Redemption 2 lets players bypass entire missions if they fail enough times, for instance—but the addition of the text-and-pictures summary is a good step toward inclusivity. Newcomers to a game, genre, or gaming as a whole can often be discouraged from taking advantage of these "skip" functions because it can feel like missing out on key parts of the experience, but the additional content provided through DS2 's boss skip feature could make it feel like an alternative way to engage with the game, rather than a sacrifice.

Boss-Skipping Is a Smart Feature for Death Stranding 2

The first Death Stranding has been criticized for many things, but one of the most significant points of contention is its boss design. Indeed, those expecting intense and intuitive boss battles often express disappointment with Death Stranding 's epic showdowns, with common critiques focusing on their integration into the broader gameplay loop, underdeveloped shooting mechanics, and the game's stiff movement controls. How one feels about these points is subjective, but it's clear that many Death Stranding players view boss fights as a weak spot.

These concerns could be addressed in Death Stranding 2 , but the sequel could also stick to its guns, as it were: its boss fights might draw the same sorts of criticisms, remaining unappealing to those who took umbridge with the boss fights of the first game; many of the "shortcomings" of Death Stranding 's bosses relate to the game's core mechanics, after all. Since so many will be playing Death Stranding for its story and novel locomotion gameplay, with little care for boss fights and combat in general, adding an exit hatch seems like a no-brainer.

Step by step, legendary game creator Hideo Kojima changes the world once again.

item.title: Oblivion Remastered Player Spots Their Real-Life Rug in the Game
item.description:
Summary

  • The rug from a player's home is also found in Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion Remastered, sparking amusement.
  • Many fans are delighted by the nostalgia of Oblivion Remastered, comparing it with Skyrim.
  • Players speculate why the identical rug is in the game, with theories about 3D scanning and design inspiration.

An Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion Remastered player was surprised to find that a rug they have in their own home is also present in the game. The odd discovery has amused the Oblivion Remastered community and stirred up some curiosity about the find.

Oblivion Remastered has been a big hit among gamers. Many Elder Scrolls fans never gave up their fondness for Oblivion , and having it back in a remastered form has delighted them. Others never went further back in the Elder Scrolls catalog than Skyrim until now, and discovering the differences between Oblivion and Skyrim has been interesting for those fans. While there's certainly a number of odd sights in Oblivion Remastered , chances are most players aren't expecting to find furniture or decorations from their own home in the game.

Nonetheless, that turned out to be the case for Reddit user nakanamaka, who discovered that the rug in their home is also in the game. The player shared a short video showing off the two, with the recording starting looking at the rug in-game, with the player then walking over to their real counterpart. While the in-game variant that can be found in Seridur's basement is quite filthy, the two rugs' designs are identical. The curious find has gotten the community talking.

Oblivion Remastered Players Muse on Matching Rugs

Several players have been amused and shared jokes about this find, teasing the OP as to how they managed to get to Cyrodiil, or that they should watch out for Oblivion gates opening up around their home, or simply referencing common memes from the game. However, some have also hypothesized as to why the in-game rug design is identical. Theories suggested include that the 3D artist responsible for the asset may have had the same rug in their own home, and based it off of that. Others suggested that it may have been a 3D scan done in Unreal Engine, which the remaster is built upon. However, Game Rant verified that the rug is also present in the original release of Oblivion .

Curiously, this isn't the only instance of this happening in a Bethesda game. Previously, one gamer realized that they owned a table identical to one in Fallout 4 . In Fallout 4 's case, it's likely that the design was intentionally replicated, as the game has a retro aesthetic that heavily draws upon the real world's 1950s. Finding a modern-day rug in a mystical fantasy game like Oblivion, on the other hand, is a bit more odd.

6 Images
6 Images

item.title: Destiny 2: Heavy Metal Title Guide
item.description:
Destiny 2 brings forth a new PvP game mode that pits player-controlled Brigs against player-controlled Tanks in this 3v3 mode. Along with a fun new PvP mode, players can earn Event Rewards such as a Combat Sparrow and a Title to further flex their veteran status as a completionist and someone who's pretty into Heavy Metal.

Heavy Metal is a cool title for a pretty fun game mode, so players might want to know all Triumphs for the Heavy Metal Title in Destiny 2 so that they can join the ranks of the elite players out there who are willing to give it their all.

Players will have until May 16, 2025, to earn the Heavy Metal Title in Destiny 2 .

How to Complete All Triumphs for the Heavy Metal Title in Destiny 2

There are 4 Triumphs players must complete if they want to earn the Heavy Metal title for their Guardians, and each of them is easily achieved simply by playing the game mode itself. While it might take a while to complete based on kills and wins, it's an achievable title for most players:

Triumph

Description

How to Complete

Vehicle Compactor

Defeat target vehicles.

Defeat 150 combatants in Heavy Metal. Assists count, so they do not need to all be Final Blows.

Kill Streak

Defeat multiple targets without dying.

Defeat at least 2 combatants before dying. This will need to be completed at least 20 times, meaning 1 point for every 2 kills.

The Undefeated

Win games.

Simply win 10 games of Heavy Metal.

I Get What I Want

Complete the Event Track in the Event Home.

Play Heavy Metal and complete the Daily Bounties in the Event Home section and earn all 15 rewards.

How to Complete All Triumphs to Get the Gilded Heavy Metal Title in Destiny 2

Once players have earned the Heavy Metal Title in Destiny 2 , there will be 4 more Triumphs that unlock. Players can complete these 4 Triumphs to acquire the Gilded version of the Heavy Metal title, which showcases mastery of the Heavy Metal game mode:

Triumph

Description

How to Complete

Usurper

Defeat your target's leader.

Kill the leader of the enemy team 20 times. The leader is noted by their orange glow and will be the enemy with the most points.

Atop the Throne

Become a leader.

Acquire the most points to become a leader, and repeat this 10 times.

Valuable Legacy

Collect leaders' coins.

Leader coins are more valuable and can be collected after defeating the enemy that is glowing orange.

Salvo Sender

Defeat targets while using the secondary weapon.

Defeat 25 targets with the secondary weapon, which can be achieved with R1.

Destiny 2

item.title: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 - Sunless Cliffs 100% Guide
item.description:
There are many different adventures to embark on in Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 outside of the emotional main story. As the game gradually allows you to explore the furthest corners of the Continent, you'll wind up finding all sorts of hidden locales that can lead to some exciting rewards.

One particularly mysterious locale in Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is the Sunless Cliffs . For those unsure, here's a rundown on where exactly to find it on the game's massively detailed map and what it entails in terms of content.

Where to Find Sunless Cliffs in Clair Obscur: Expedition 33

The Sunless Cliffs is one of the more elusive optional locations found in Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 , as it's tucked within a crevice on top of a cliff. You can find its colorful portal southeast of Sirene island and also a Gestral Beach location to the east of it.

To reach the Sunless Cliffs portal, you will need to have access to Esquie's flying ability, which requires a certain amount of progress in the main story (specifically the end of Act 2). This is because the portal itself is nestled on a raised cliff ledge surrounded by water on either side, so swimming won't do the trick this time.

It's just as well, because the content within Sunless Cliffs poses a significant challenge best suited for true endgame progression, so don't worry about rushing to dive in too quickly.

How to Complete Sunless Cliffs in Clair Obscur: Expedition 33

Once inside, you'll find that the Sunless Cliffs is a relatively small location. From the entrance, there isn't much to find or see besides the ominous eclipse over the monolith ahead. Run forward until the path diverts left and right. The left route leads to a short dead end with nothing there, so don't bother. Instead, head to the right and into the tunnel.

On the other side of the tunnel, you'll find a rather unsettling room with a huge portal structure and an Expedition Flag nearby. This is the main feature of the Sunless Cliffs, and you'll want to be thoroughly prepared with polished builds for the difficult challenge that lies on the other side. Attempting this challenge is not recommended until your party is at least Level 80 , if not max level , with upgraded weapons and Pictos that heartily buff your characters' stats.

This is especially because, upon interacting with the portal, you'll find that only one party member is allowed to enter . In other words, you will only have one character to use in the fight ahead, similar to fights with Gestral Merchants. As such, you will need to choose very wisely.

How to Defeat the Sunless Cliffs Mime

The challenge that lies within the portal turns out to be one of the game's many different Mime boss encounters. However, this is considered the most difficult one in the entire game, as if its menacing red eyes weren't telling enough.

Just like all other Mimes, this one will start the fight by building up a "wall" in front of it, boosting its defense stat considerably. It'll also employ the same two familiar attacks, one being a 3-hit melee combo, while the other sees it brandishing a hammer and attempting to flatten its target over 5 hits. The strategy needed to defeat it is thankfully also the same; it involves using your party's attacks to fill the yellow 'Break' gauge below its health bar.

Once the gauge is 'broken' with an appropriate attack, the Mime will be temporarily stunned, and its defense stat will lower back to its original level, allowing you to bombard it with your most powerful moves for heavy damage the rest of the fight.

In the case of this Mime, however, with its combat stats inherently being very high, it's not nearly as easy to survive its attacks, should one land. If you're underleveled and/or undergeared, this Mime can easily one-hit KO your one party member. This makes dodging such punishing damage a priority, and your attacks need to be punishing enough in return to build its 'Break' gauge as fast as possible.

Once you manage to defeat this Mime, the fight will reward you with 'The One' Pictos (first time only) along with a 'Bald' haircut for the character you used in that respective fight. Unlike other Mimes in the game, this fight can be repeated as often as needed if you want to get the same bald look for your entire party.
